title: Bladder and Bowel Issues With MS – Part 1

content: I drink a lot of water daily as a way of managing fatigue. Typically, I feel like my “tubes” and my insides in general overheat, meaning my esophagus, my tongue, etc., feel hot. I know; it’s weird. So, I find that drinking ice-cold water all day as I need minimizes those symptoms. That’s why I keep with me an insulated bottle of water filled with ice and I refill it as I go.

Fatigue is always present, so there’s no way out of drinking rivers of water for me. Which takes me to my next point. I have to use the restroom many times a day. I also feel overheated while I’m sleeping. It literally wakes me up. So, the strategy to stop drinking water by 6 p.m. and to prevent using the bathroom at night doesn’t work for me because I’m constantly needing water.

I thought that I just needed to use the bathroom all the time because of my excessive water intake, but no. I just found out through my urogynecologist that I have an overactive (spastic) bladder . My bladder can’t hold urine as long as normal, and I feel a frequent urge to urinate. This is caused by the interruption of signals sent from my brain to my bladder, due to MS.

content: According to the test performed at my doctor’s office, my bladder is able to empty properly, but it urges me to go frequently. Another thing I get with this is the hesitancy to start urination. This is nothing more than having to push when trying to urinate. It’s kind of a double standard: I feel the urge to go even if it’s just a little bit, but then I have trouble urinating and I have to push.

Nocturia, or frequent urination at nighttime, can also be a symptom of bladder dysfunction with multiple sclerosis. Waking up several times at night to use the restroom disrupts your sleep, and we know how important it is for us to rest. I had this problem for several years, and it really compromised my sleep hygiene, and the consequence was always severe fatigue.

content: Most recently, I’ve noticed that it’s taking me more time to leave the house because I need to empty my bladder several times. Also, everywhere I go, I have to locate the bathroom and empty as soon as I get there and right before leaving, to avoid problems. So, in a way, it feels like I’m planning my day around my bladder issues. Also, If I don’t empty my bladder when needed, another of my many symptoms arises: hypersensitivity.

content: Throughout the day, I struggle with hypersensitivity, which could show as a “buzzing” sensation inside of me, or “burning skin,” “shock waves,” or “freezing hands and feet.” When it’s really bad, even my clothes bother me – so much so that I don’t want to be touched. It’s very uncomfortable.

I mentioned to my former neurologist that if I hold my urine, I feel that my skin starts to burn. He told me that I’m not the first patient that has mentioned that to him, which makes me feel better, of course. I know now that I’m not crazy. But also, it confirms that there’s an undeniable correlation between MS and bladder dysfunction.

As bizarre as these symptoms sound, they’re real. Aren’t we lucky? Had they warned me or told me about all the things that come with living with multiple sclerosis on the day of my diagnosis, I would’ve probably lost my mind. At least I’m getting them little by little, over time.

content: According to the National MS Society, 80% of the people living with multiple sclerosis live with bladder dysfunction. This can cause frequent urinary tract infections that could compromise overall health, as well as other serious complications.

During my visit to the urogynecologist, I learned that there’s something really cool for us ladies called a female urination device. It’s like a “funnel” for us to urinate standing up like men do. Pretty cool, huh? I found it super helpful. In case you’re traveling or there’s no bathroom available, you can still relieve yourself.

content: This device could come in handy when taking road trips, which is something I really enjoy doing, or when going camping or doing any other outdoor activity. There’s also a variety of portable folding and/or retractable toilets, compact enough to use inside a car.

Speaking about traveling, using the restroom in an airplane with mobility issues is a big challenge. There’s not enough space in the bathroom for someone like me, wearing a full leg brace, let alone somebody in a wheelchair. I personally have to undo the upper half of my brace to use the restroom, which comes out to the side once undone because it’s still attached to the other lower half of the brace. Therefore, I need more space to sit on the toilet and to undo and redo the brace.

content: Whether you struggle with incontinence, overactive bladder, or neurogenic bladder, it’s better to prepare for emergencies from this point forward, which could include wearing disposable absorbing underwear or pads, incontinence products like adult diapers, bringing a change of clothes, wearing easily removable clothes like joggers with an elastic waistband, etc.
Now, there is another even messier issue that MS can bring to us, and that is the loss of bowel control, which can also be associated with constipation, ironically. Both are undesirable either way.
I can’t think of anything more embarrassing than having “an accident” in public. Well, it could happen to the best of us, MSers.
Yes, I’ll dive into that in Part 2 of this blog, so stay tuned.
